Lack enough support: The claim is based on a picture shared on Twitter and picked up by blogs and online newspapers, but there is no substantial evidence or verification provided to support the claim that pastors have invited Jesus Christ on an Africa tour.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the person shown in the picture is actually Jesus Christ, without providing any evidence or proof to support this assumption.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Jesus has come back and landed in Kenya first, without any credible evidence to support this extraordinary claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on social media posts, blogs, and online newspapers as sources, which may not always provide accurate information or reliable sources.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the possibility that the person shown in the picture may be an impersonator or someone falsely claiming to be Jesus Christ.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the person shown in the picture is actually Michael Job, an evangelist, and not Jesus Christ.
Understate: No biases related to understating are evident in the claim.
